Package org.jtrim2.event

Class CopyOnTriggerListenerManager<ListenerType>

java.lang.Object
org.jtrim2.event.CopyOnTriggerListenerManager<ListenerType>
Type Parameters:
ListenerType - the type of the event handlers can possibly be added to the container
All Implemented Interfaces:
ListenerManager<ListenerType>, ListenerRegistry<ListenerType>, SimpleListenerRegistry<ListenerType>
public final class CopyOnTriggerListenerManager<ListenerType> extends Object implements ListenerManager<ListenerType>
An ListenerManager implementation which creates a copy of the currently registered listeners when dispatching events. That is, in the onEvent method, it first creates copy of the currently added listeners as done by the getListeners() method and then dispatches the event to all of them.

This implementation allows to register the same listener multiple times and listeners registered multiple times will be notified multiple times as well when dispatching events.

Adding and removing listeners are constant time operations but, of course, dispatching events requires linear time in the number of registered listeners (plus the time the listeners need).

Thread safety

As required by ListenerManager, the methods of this class are safe to be accessed concurrently by multiple threads.

Synchronization transparency

As required by ListenerManager, except for the onEvent method, methods of this class are synchronization transparent.

  • Method Details

    • registerListener

      public ListenerRef registerListener(ListenerType listener)
      Adds an event listener to this container and returns a reference which can later be used to removed the listener added.

      Subsequent event notifications will notify the added listener unless it is removed using the returned reference.

      It doesn't matter if the listener was already added. In case the given listener have been added to this ListenerRegistry it will be added again causing the added listener to be notified as many times as it has been added. Note that the equals method of the listener should have no effect regarding this ListenerRegistry.

      If a listener is removed but it was added multiple times, it will be removed only once. So, further event notifications will be delivered to the listener one less time.

      Implementation note: Adding and removing (using the returned reference) a listener is a constant time operation.

      Specified by:
      registerListener in interface ListenerRegistry<ListenerType>
      Specified by:
      registerListener in interface SimpleListenerRegistry<ListenerType>
      Parameters:
      listener - the listener to be added to this container and be notified in subsequent event notifications method calls. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      the reference which can be used to remove the currently added listener. This method never returns null.

    • onEvent

      public <ArgType> void onEvent(EventDispatcher<? super ListenerType,? super ArgType> eventDispatcher, ArgType arg)
      Invokes the onEvent method of the specified EventDispatcher with the currently registered listeners and the argument specified. The onEvent method is called synchronously in the current thread.

      Adding new listeners to this container will have no effect on the current call and the listeners being notified. That is, if a notified listener adds a new listener to this container, the newly added listener will not be notified in this call, only in subsequent onEvent calls.

      The order in which the listener are notified is undefined. Also note, that multiply added listener might be notified multiple times depending on the exact implementation.

      Note that usually it is required that event listeners be invoked in the order the events occur. This can easily be done when events can only occur on single thread (as they do in Swing). However, when events can occur on multiple threads concurrently they are likely to occur while holding a lock and listeners should be notified right away to be notified of the event to keep the order of events. Note that calling an event handler method while holding a lock is prone to dead-lock (and it is very likely to be possible since it is hard to reason about what listeners might do). In this case you should consider using a TaskScheduler to invoke the onEvent method.

      Implementation note: In case an exception is thrown by a registered listener, other listeners will still be invoked. The thrown exception will be logged on a SEVERE log level.

      Specified by:
      onEvent in interface ListenerManager<ListenerType>
      Type Parameters:
      ArgType - the type of the argument which is passed to event listeners
      Parameters:
      eventDispatcher - the EventDispatcher whose onEvent method is to be called for every registered listener with the specified argument. The onEvent method will be called as many times as many currently registered listeners are (i.e.: the number the getListenerCount() method returns). This argument cannot be null.
      arg - the argument to be passed to every invocation of the onEvent method of the specified EventDispatcher. This argument can be null if the EventDispatcher allows for null arguments.
      See Also:
      • TaskScheduler

    • getListenerCount

      public int getListenerCount()
      Returns the number of currently added but not yet removed listeners.

      Implementation note: Retrieving the number of listeners is a constant time operation.

      Specified by:
      getListenerCount in interface ListenerRegistry<ListenerType>
      Returns:
      the number of currently added but not yet removed listeners. This method always returns an integer greater than or equal to zero.
